original_data.question: A 32-year-old man arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his fear of flying. The patient reports that he has had a fear of flying since being a teenager. He went on a family vacation 15 years ago, and during the flight there was turbulence and a “rough landing”. Since then he has avoided flying. He did not go to his cousin’s wedding because it was out of the country. He also was unable to visit his grandmother for her 80th birthday. The last time his job asked him to meet a client out of state, he drove 18 hours instead of flying. Two years ago he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida. Upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel dizzy, lightheaded, and refused to go through security. During the clinic visit, the patient appears anxious and distressed. He recognizes that his fear is irrational. He is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients. He is embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his fear of flying. Which of the following is the best therapy for the patient’s condition?

model_response:
The patient’s fear of flying is consistent with a diagnosis of specific phobia. The avoidance of air travel is leading to functional impairment and the patient recognizes the irrationality of his fear. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the treatment of choice for specific phobias. CBT involves education about the irrationality of fears, identification of maladaptive thoughts, and changing behaviors to overcome the fear. Medications, such as alprazolam, can be used for short-term relief of anxiety, but long-term management involves behavioral therapy. Fluoxetine is an antidepressant that may be used in the treatment of specific phobias, but it is not the first-line treatment. Psychodynamic psychotherapy is not the treatment of choice for specific phobias.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
The affective response to an actual current external danger which subsides with the elimination of the threatening condition.
to move in or pass through the air with wings; this is for the act of movement through air by wings; for transportation by airplane use AVIATION.

An indication that the patient provides information about their vital signs, status, or subjective feelings. Some systems also consider information reported by the patient's family or guardian as patient-reported.

to move in or pass through the air with wings; this is for the act of movement through air by wings; for transportation by airplane use AVIATION.

Leisure time away from work devoted to rest or pleasure.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Self-propelled movement of an organism from one location to another through the air, usually by means of active wing movement. [GOC:dph]

A child of your aunt or uncle or their descendents.
The social event at which the ceremony of marriage is performed.

A collective generic term that refers here to a wide variety of dependencies, areas of special sovereignty, uninhabited islands, and other entities in addition to the traditional countries or independent states.
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
The day of the week on which a person was born.
Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.
A person who pays for goods or services.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.

A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

An intent to perform a service that has the strength of a commitment, i.e., other parties may rely on the originator of such promise that said originator will see to it that the promised act will be fulfilled. A promise can be either solicited or unsolicited.
State bounded on east by the Atlantic Ocean, on the south by the Gulf of Mexico, on the west by Alabama and on the north by Alabama and Georgia.

The relationship that links to a Transportation Act (target) from another Act (source) indicating that the subject of the source Act entered into the source Act by means of the target Transportation act.
Terminal facilities used for aircraft takeoff and landing and including facilities for handling passengers. (from McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed.)
An imprecise term which may refer to a sense of spatial disorientation, motion of the environment, or lightheadedness.
A feeling of faintness; a reeling sensation. Lightheadedness is medically distinct from dizziness, unsteadiness, and vertigo.
Services provided to prevent, deter, detect and/or document crime, fire, disorder or violations of company rules.
Those facilities which administer health services to individuals who do not require hospitalization or institutionalization.
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
A feeling of worry and unhappiness.

To be influenced by or changed.
A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something.
A female partner in marriage.
Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.
Members of the various professions (e.g., PHYSICIANS) or occupations (e.g., POLICE).
The likelihood or possibility that a specific state or condition will exist or that an action will occur.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
